docs.snippet: Frank Simek has had his taste of the big time, and he wants more.     ''I was pleased with my debut,'' he said in a telephone interview from London. ''I want to keep pushing up to the first team.''
docs.lead_paragraph: Frank Simek has had his taste of the big time, and he wants more. ''I was pleased with my debut,'' he said in a telephone interview from London. ''I want to keep pushing up to the first team.''
docs.abstract: American defender Frank Simek makes good debut in game with Arsenal senior team (M)

docs.snippet: THE bad news for caviar lovers this holiday season is that fresh Russian caviar from the 2003 catch is all but impossible to find. The good news is that there are many fine alternatives, and that international regulations are increasingly effective...
docs.lead_paragraph: THE bad news for caviar lovers this holiday season is that fresh Russian caviar from the 2003 catch is all but impossible to find. The good news is that there are many fine alternatives, and that international regulations are increasingly effective in guaranteeing the quality and authenticity of what is sold. This year, red tape has held up the shipping of Russian caviar, and it could take weeks before any of it shows up in American stores. The Russian caviar that is for sale here is, at best, from the 2002 catch. But some of the caviar labeled Russian is actually from Kazakhstan, on the Caspian Sea. Most of that caviar is also from 2002.
docs.abstract: Fresh Russian caviar from 2003 catch is all but impossible to find in New York this year, but there are many fine alternatives; international regulations are increasingly effective in guaranteeing quality and authenticity of what is sold (M)

headline.main: Casting for Caviar, in the Caspian and Beyond

docs.snippet: The emergence of a case of mad cow disease in the United States this week has created an unparalleled opportunity for Brazil and Argentina, two of the main competitors of the United States in the booming international beef export market, to capture...
docs.lead_paragraph: The emergence of a case of mad cow disease in the United States this week has created an unparalleled opportunity for Brazil and Argentina, two of the main competitors of the United States in the booming international beef export market, to capture new customers, government and industry officials here say. Cattle in both countries graze on grass; they are not fed ground-up animal parts that have been used as feed elsewhere, a practice believed to transmit mad cow disease.
docs.abstract: Brazilian officials say emergence of case of mad cow disease in US has created unparalleled opportunity for Brazil and Argentina, two of main competitors of US in international beef export market, to capture new customers; photo of Argentine cattle (M)

headline.main: Brazil and Argentina Expect Rising Beef Sales
headline.kicker: MAD COW DISEASE IN THE UNITED STATES: EXPORTS

docs.snippet: Every Monday and Tuesday, when Sunday newspapers from across Latin America arrive at their store in Jackson Heights, Queens, Hilda and Emilio Luna get to work. The immigrant couple -- she is from Peru, he from Uruguay -- set aside copies for loyal...
docs.lead_paragraph: Every Monday and Tuesday, when Sunday newspapers from across Latin America arrive at their store in Jackson Heights, Queens, Hilda and Emilio Luna get to work. The immigrant couple -- she is from Peru, he from Uruguay -- set aside copies for loyal customers they know will stop by over the next few days. Then, the Lunas stuff 30 to 40 priority-mail envelopes for the loyal customers who they know will not stop by, and for good reason: they are in prison.
docs.abstract: Article on Hilda and Emilio Luna, owners of El Turf shop in Jackson Heights, Queens, who have carved out niche by sending Latin American newspapers and magazines to prisoners nationwide; photo (M)

headline.main: Nothing in the World, But Time to Read
